columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the effect of tax change in tax law to the relative attractiveness of stock repurchases compared to dividend payments.

Basically, stock repurchases are taxed at a capital gains tax rate, while the dividends are subject to ordinary income tax. If dividends have high tax and capital gains have low tax, shareholders will prefer stock repurchases over dividends and the attractiveness of stock repurchases will increase.
This exercise will determine the effect of taxes on the attractiveness of stock repurchases over the distribution of dividends.

### KEY TERMS

* **Share repurchase (Share buybacks)** - this is where the corporation's shares are previously issued and then reacquired by the issuing entity. These shares are not necessarily canceled, it is just treated as a contra-equity account since it is deducted from the total amount of shareholdersâ€™ equity.

* **Dividends** - refers to the resources earned by the entity that is paid out to its shareholders. This may be in the form of cash, property, or stocks.

Most investors would rather choose to pay for the capital gains tax rather than the taxes imposed on dividends. The main reason is that higher rates are being imposed on the dividends as compared to the securities being sold in the market.

Moreover, capital gains tax can be deferred until the securities were sold, unlike the dividends that have to be paid whether the shareholders would adhere to it or not.

One of the reasons why corporations buy back their previously issued shares is to make their share of stocks financially attractive. The reacquisition of shares decreases the number of outstanding common shares that are used as a denominator in the earnings per share computation. A higher number of shares repurchased will lead to higher earnings per share and vice versa.
